job_title: Registered Medical Assistant in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: I met some of the nicest people to work with there. Some of the doctors were great to work and easy-going.
cons: Manager was flaky, the medical director didn't have a clue what was going on, and certain medical assistants got special treatment over others for not doing their job. You would think after working there for 20+ years there would be some level of respect, but I was still I was easily replaceable. My yearly reviews didn't count for anything to receive a decent merit raise. I was given 0.8 cent to 0.10 cent raises after great reviews and was told it was because I had been there so long and they wished they could give me more. It was so frustrating to work so hard and to be rewarded with basically nothing year after year, or the last one was giving the same amount to everyone across the board, even if they didn't do as well on their reviews. Not fair in my book.

job_title: Front Desk Medical Receptionist in Pontiac, MI
pros: Patients were always polite & early to their appointments for the most part
cons: I worked for Trinity Health-IHA The Management SUCKS, I put in my 2 week notice and Then on my last day I went in and was there for an hour, my boss pulled me into her office to have a meeting and she then told me I was wrong for putting in my 2 week notice & that I needed to hand in my badge and drawer keys now. Previously, she extended my 90 day probationary period because I wasn’t chit chatting with my co workers, When I hired in I was told after 90 days you get part of a $1,000 bonus. I didn’t get to touch any part of that bonus because I didn’t chit chat with my coworkers. This boss always seemed to have a problem with the way I was doing something ( even as simple as checking people in) I was trained and I asked questions daily but that still want enough. She had expectations for me to be just as good as the other 2 receptionist who have 10+ years of experience and I have never even done this before. Everytime you would get up to go to the rest room or whatever the employees would be nice to your face but talk so much crap about you as soon as you leave because they as grown 50 year old women didn’t think you could hear them. As I type this my last day was yesterday and my boss refused to let me work a full day like usual and then I got an exit survey in my email and come to find out when I go to do it this morning I have no access anymore. One last thing is that my boss and 2 others were able to leave for a week and I handled the front desk great, but she still didn’t think I was good enough for her. She allowed 3 other people to leave early EVERYDAY but I had to stay until 5 and lock up even though I was the new hire..

review_title: Trinity Health IS Service Desk Support
job_title: Service Desk Support in Livonia, MI
pros: - Working remotely - Great insurance benefits/wellness initiative discount - Pay is pretty good especially if you don't have a college degree - It takes a lot for you to get fired (Most leave for a better external opportunity and a few transfer internally. You would either have to be late every shift or terrible at your job even after multiple attempts at re-training.)
cons: - If you've been at the Service Desk longer than a year or two, that will work against you when you apply to internal positions in a different department. - Most managers from other departments view Service Desk employees as simple call takers that read directly from a script, even though we take very complex calls at times and have very diverse backgrounds. - Some of the doctors/nurses/hospital staff/second level IT staff are some of the most disrespectful people I've ever dealt with in my life. - Things are rolled out without proper change management processes and the Service Desk takes the brunt of the frustration from the users. Second level techs may not take responsibility for fixing the issues until some high up doctor complains. - Run of the mill office politics. If management doesn't like you, you will stay in your level 1 position forever and will not be given a straight answer as to why.

review_title: If I knew then, what I know now...
pros: The primary reason I am still employed with this hospital is only because of the friendships I have established in working here. I have met some pretty amazing people who have made each day coming in "worth it". The team I work with on my shifts are incredible along with the lead officers who are amazing and have really helped keep us together.
cons:
* There are absolutely no incentives for the security department as there is for many other departments in the hospital. 
* We have been working "mandatory" twelve/+ hour shifts and are understaffed because of the extreme demands put on us that have caused several of us to quit combined with 95% of the department having caught COVID within the past 9 months. 
* The inadequate amount of pay with the higher cost of living in our area is more than challenging.

pros: Trinity Senior Services runs nursing homes including the Alverno in Clinton Iowa. Especially a mixture of long term care and skilled care. The interviewer took my solution to the problem and within a month, we had new equipment that solved the problem of nurses who do not often get to draw blood or start IVS. It was awesome!
cons: 12 hour shifts in long term care is entirely to long to work. pros: Staff is great, lots of opportunities to pick up shifts, great teamwork with staff.
cons: Kronos. The attendance policy is absurd. It needs to be revamped completely because the turnover is way too high because of it. People should not be penalized for calling in sick so instead they risk bringing it in and harming their patients which decreases patient satisfaction and safety! Getting a 1/4 of a point for not punching in after lunch is absurd or not punching out at the end of the day, or if you are more than 59 seconds late you get a 1/4 of a point so if a patient stops you and asks for help you can’t help them unless you want points! The turnover rate has been so high and they have all said they are looking forward to no longer having to deal with Kronos. Quality letters and chart prep too. We don’t have time for things to be added on because overtime isn’t allowed yet things continue to get added onto our days while nothing gets taken away and patients don’t pay attention to the letters we send anyway.

review_title: Too many chiefs not enough Indians
pros: Good Pay, great for gaining experience, work/life balance, ability to work from home from time to time.
cons: Many people have left the company since the merger due to lack of cohesiveness and uncertainty about their jobs.  Decisions are made without communication between both sides. The amount of meetings are counterproductive especially when people are battling back and forth about their ideas. The morale is down especially amongst individual contributors and lower management. Senior management is in and out the door, lower managers have no real power to institute change nor do they care at this point, and the individual contributors have no real voice (although they're encouraged to speak - yeah right!) Raises and advancement opportunities are nearly non-existent. Individuals from the CHE feel that the Trinity folks are all snobs and know-it-alls while individuals from Trinity feel that the CHE folks are all incompetent. For someone who is trying to remain neutral, it is not a good scene to watch.

job_title: Diet Aide in Turners Falls, MA
pros: Good pay, good hours and flexible schedules, you can pretty much have as much or as little as you would like since it's fairly small and not many set schedules with most people being students that can't work often as it is. The work is very repetitive and can be overwhelming at first, but gets very easy and becomes almost a secondary task to you, I've only been there a month and have it down pretty good. The residents are usually very kind and can be a joy to be around when you have to go up to the floors and stock kitchens or bring them food and the likes. I've had a few conversations with them, and sometimes the obnoxious randomness that they do is funny to me so it brings me a nice smile in the middle of a work day.
cons: Fast paced, this can be a pro however to some people. Can be unpredictable at times due to the nature of working in a kitchen, mistakes are bound to happen. Some of the work gets kinda gross and gets you dirty if you're washing dishes/pots (I wash pots). The residents could be troublesome to some people, but usually are fairly tame (besides some screaming but you can deal with that. to me it's usually very comedic).

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse Charge Nurse in Saint Clair Shores, MI

job_title: Registered Nurse in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I worked as a Registered Nurse at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital Ann Arbor, MI. It was a good starting position but there is almost no room for advancement unless you go back to school for an MSN or other advanced degree.
cons: There is no room for salary negotiation and when I advanced my position from a general Med/Surg unit to the ICU, I took a pay cut for taking on more responsibility. The hospital is frequently on a hiring freeze and always short staffed so working at dangerously unsafe conditions for patients and my RN license. When I schedule a few days off, I am always receiving phone calls asking me to come in and work. Sometimes, they are crafty and will say, "Where are you?" implying that I am supposed to be at work and will even go so far as to say that I was on the schedule. So I will rush over thinking it was my mistake only to find out that I was not on the schedule and they would trick me and say, "Well, since you're here already...want to stay?" No support from management.

review_title: Lack of leadership by owners, lack of concern for workers in the trenches
pros:
Excellent training on the technical aspects of the job; great instructors.
One quickly learns how to work in the trenches.
One learns how to conduct informational classes for clients.
Many of the nurses and mental health workers care deeply about the work they do with patients on the behavioral health wards.
Great employee cafeteria and service staff
cons:
Inadequate, understaffed, and poorly trained security personnel
Ineffective employee union
Learning the application of the techniques taught during training is done alone and under fire
Overloaded, overworked, and unappreciated nursing staff
Some of the docs are arrogant, dismissive, and condescending to nurses, staff, and patients
Compliments and rewards are withheld from staff despite often amazing work; fear of the owner's wrath is fomented
Lazy old-timers tolerated
Resistant to change
Glaring, dangerous errors are covered up rather than used as teachable moments, and infighting, bullying, finger-pointing and backstabbing amongst the nursing and mental health staff is de rigeur.  A culture of disrespect between the nurses and the MHCs is growing.  Cooperation is not likely to happen in an environment where people, rather than problems, are attacked by an upper management team concerned more with the illusion of amity and effectiveness than making it a reality.

pros:
Trinity Health has a strong mission and well-defined purpose. The values are well thought out by the founding sisters, and ministries recently acquired.  I respect the new CEO and COO who are attempting to make a difference to ensure the company’s sustainability. 
Enjoyed working with a dynamic team, but unfortunately the most talented do not stay due to reckless politics practiced by long-term leaders.
cons: While there were many downsides, there is one word that rings true if one should decide to work for Trinity Health – Beware.  Middle management, upper management, and senior leaders use words like “plausible deniability.”. Because of this, there is little tribal knowledge or accountability. This mindset has stunted operational growth, and in some areas, this organization operates in the dark ages.

review_title: Trinity Health - A great place to work.
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Novi, MI
pros: Trinity Health is a great place to work.  Being part of a company that actually saves lives is a great feeling, even if you never talk a patient.  A great benefits package - 4 weeks of paid time off (sick and vacation time all rolled into 1), 403b (401k for non-profits), pension plan, medical, dental, vision, life & disability insurance and tuition reimbursement ($2,500/year).  Also, in the IT department, there are many opportunities for career advancement.  Internal candidates for openings are preferred.
cons:
Trinity Health does pay competitive wages, but working for a Healthcare non-profit will not pay as well as other industries.
Supporting multiple hospital systems across the country requires 24x7 IT support, some people may not not appreciate being paged at 3am to help a doctor, know what you are signing up for in advance.

review_title: PCT & RN at Saint Joseph mercy hospital Ann Arbor
job_title: Registered Nurse in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Benefits 
8 and 12 hour shifts available 
Pay is decent
Parking
Good diversity. 
Don't force you to cover up tattoos and piercings.
cons:
Recruiters-Not helpful finding jobs on different units and can actually prevent you from seeking out better positions because they control what managers will see your resume. I talked with an ER manager and he said he would have to talk to the recruiter to see if he could interview me -_-

Unit managers- Some are great! Love 1 East manager. 4 North and and the Ace unit? No. She can't handle her job position and is very rude.

Money based. Do not really care about their patients.

pros: The co-workers are the only positive thing! Trinity or CHE, Mercy whatever they are called now. Not matter pro's to list. The "little people" just love what they do, not who they do it for.
cons: Don't get hurt working for them. Trinity/CHE/Mercy will drag you through the workers comp process as long as possible to hurt you more, no matter the severity of your injuries. They will treat you like a criminal no matter how many years you have them. They will spend more money making your life miserable than doing the right thing. Big difference from "taking care of the needy". You, your family or your kids do not matter to them. If you can imagine your worst fear or nightmare, working for them will make it a reality. They say they care about you and your family and I can tell you first hand that is false!! Don't complain to HR because as my department supervisor "EMS Chief" put it "I will know if you went to HR". If you like being treated like crap, not respected for years of service, giving your all and getting dumped on then this is the place for you.

pros: Great employees to work with (Those who are left and haven't been replaced by outsourcing).. I wish I had more good to say, but poor pay, bad work environment, worthless benefits, no overtime, outsourced management, shrinking core workforce and an HR department that hires based on who you know makes it tough to find pros!
cons: Horrible revolving door of incompetent overpaid Managers, Supervisors and Directors mostly brought in from 3rd party companies. Constant turn over of management. No one knows what they are doing or how to manage people. More and more work is being outsourced to outside companies to save money.

review_title: Needs incentives for employees to stay
pros: Always busy which makes the time go by faster. Close to home.  Business/Casual dress. Onsite coffee shop. Nice desk area.
cons: The computers employees use are old and have old software. I've worked there for over 3 years and we recently migrated to Microsoft Outlook from Group Wise. Many departments use paper for everything and management is not up to date on technology or trends in healthcare or in human resources. Many in management do not have previous management experience and/or degrees and it is sometimes challenging to work with management who are not up to date on trends and use the statement "that's how we've always done it".  Benefits are not the best. Working for a healthcare system you would expect the best but not here. Also, not enough Time Off is provided. If you want to take time off during the holidays you have to use your PTO time?!  Not enough telecommuting opportunities.

pros: Some great nurses work there, weekend pay (union) is top notch. Some excellent specialists. Although the definite minority, some doctors are excellent.
cons: No communication between departments. Orders go in and nobody tells you why, you have to search the record to uncover reasoning many times. Pts want to know why changes are happening. Too many hands in the pot, interns write orders. You implement, then they are changed or dc'ed constantly t/o the day by attending or resident. Lot of AMA's bc many interns and residents won't call attending but don't feel comfortable DCing pts. Little or no accountability from other departments for delays in care. Nurses spend too much time trying to get doctors or other departments to do their jobs.

pros: The Revenue Integrity Department has a lot of potential to significantly effect positive change for the organization with the understanding of regulations and requirements between departments. This department can facilitate improvements in processes, policy and procedures within departments as well as between the different areas.The staff are knowledgeable and great to work with.
cons: There is a negative attitude towards the patients/customers. Staff lack patience or manners with the general public. Young staff personal are rude and expectations are out of line with normal places of work. There is a lot of favoritism and cliques in departments.

review_title: One of the best SNFs I have ever worked
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Holyoke, MA
pros: They do lots of little staff appreciation days. Mostly food. Which for nurses is awesome. They usually have good coverage for shifts, but at time the CNA or RNs were short on the floor, but the team would pull together and get everything done. There is a lot of loving care given to the residents here.
cons: Short term rehab had two nurses, a med nurse and a nurse who would do a head to toe assessment and discharge planning for all the short term patients. Plus the Admisions. And discharges. And narcotics for those patients. Which nurse was which would get confusing for the patients. Also, that nurse would be the first nurse to be pulled if someone called out. So it was treated like a bonus nurse rather than an actual necessity for the very medically challenging 12 sub acute patients.

review_title: Most disorganized company I have ever seen.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Farmington Hills, MI
pros: Most co-workers are friendly and helpful. Patients are wonderful and make coming to work everyday worthwhile. Not much else I can say positive.
cons: Extremely disorganized. No one knows what they are doing from day to day. More work is given then can possibly be done in a day. Expectations change constantly and usually with very little warning. Policies/procedures change and only half of the staff are made aware.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Holyoke, MA
pros: Enjoyed my work, enjoyed my co-workers, and loved my people for whom i worked for.! I had the benefits, they were good, and my people that i took care of, i'm a true Nurse that enjoys the Elderly! I intend to return here, but for now, i continue with physical therapy, i have been 2 yrs with 3 surgeries, but i want to go back and work, am 70 yrs old, but it doesn't matter to me, enjoyment of working does matter!
cons: Sometimes we were short of staff, but the Staff pulled together, and helped one another. It was a downfall, but some people did not come in to do their shift.

pros: Excellent benefits package, nice coworkers, encouragement of growth and developing your talents.
cons: Compensation below average, high risk of burnout. Lots of politics, management will sometimes play favorites even though they are supposed to treat everyone consistently. Has an attitude of "burn 'em and turn 'em" when it comes to hourly employees. If you are experiencing the side effects of burnout, it is best not to disclose it at the workplace as it could very well be used against you. It's better to quietly find another job and put in your notice instead of trying to tough it out or ask for assistance. Even though the company has a policy of no retaliation, and even though it's illegal, they will retaliate if you ask for an accommodation.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Farmington Hills, MI
pros: Strong positive culture, talented executive and senior leadership team, diligent financial management, dedicated associates, innovative, desire to be employer and health care provider of choice, productive investment in information technology and highly integrated electronic medical records.
cons: Burnout pace, heavy workloads, average benefits, average salary, weak managerial performance evaluation process and insufficient budget for salary merit increases, difficult to reach concensus across all Ministry Organizations.

pros: Mission; work life balance (remote opportunities, depending on manager)
cons: High tolerance for underperforming staff and leaders; you may earn a 4.5% raise, but you’ll only get 2-3% regardless of performance (“because we are poor”); no bonuses (only director or above); no extras (eg gym, childcare, etc); every few years they eliminate the measly 3% 403b match (“because we are poor”); limited holidays (New Years day, Memorial Day, Labor Day, only thanksgiving day, only Christmas Day); very limited management support for career development and interns growth

job_title: Billing and Follow Up Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: I had a manager, who I felt gave her all. She was available 24/7 especially after COVID-19. She was more concerned about the patients and her team, than the company’s bottom line. I also recognized that she worked with other managers to help them accomplish goals.
cons:
After my manager left, the vail was lifted. She took the brunt of things. Leadership from managers on up do not care about the team. They only care about looking good. Many have no working knowledge of the healthcare industry. My previous manager had knowledge of everything and could jump in. But not now.
Also if you are a POC...you’re not getting the job. My manager was the only female POC and could speak about not just her area, but others.

job_title: Procurement Specialist in Farmington Hills, MI
pros: The health benefits and paid time off, hire w/in the system after 1 year commitment, the overall guiding principals and behaviors make it a unique environment unlike most big businesses.
cons: If you are a newer employee, with an education and years of experience it is very difficult to get into a position that is equal to or one step below where your last job was.  Most often one has to start at the bottom and work up.  W/ experience and education, this is alot to ask in combination w/ extremely low wage, and a full year commitment before looking w/in the system.  hard to live on low salary.  With a very low salary, they give you tons and tons of work to do.

pros: Medical and dental benefits, PTO, ability to pick up extra hours.  My direct supervisor is fantastic, she has my back and I can bring any issue, big or small to her.  My pay rate here is fantastic.
cons: Can only go to Saint Mary's affiliates for medical and any testing has to be done at the hospital (bloodwork, Ultrasound, xray).  Not enough float coverage for aides.  Some nurses in a certain unit think that they are above taking patients to the bathroom or various other small things.  They will seek out an aide instead of taking care of it themselves.

review_title: Trinity Information Services is a fast-paced work environment you need to learn to communicate to stay a part of.
job_title: Clinical Applications Analyst in Farmington Hills, MI
pros: They work hard on making it as much of a community as possible with a full day class on the expectations they have for the work culture and collaboration between colleagues.  They have a positive approach to healthcare and keeping the patient the primary focus.
cons: Management can be too outcomes focused and miss the needs of the individual employees and their unique circumstances to make their abilities truly shine.  Productivity is sometimes valued over quality of effort.

review_title: Stressful working in the LAB dept.
pros: Good pay. Good parking for employees
cons: Expected to much from Phlebos. Its all about a numbers ,im referring to how many patients were drawn that day on your shift. Sometimes it might take a little longer drawing blood from a geriatric patients then another patient. Supervisor are all are Time and Numbers. And there should be more phlebos in the lab dept. That can help out in the whole hospital instead of just staying the the laboratory talking away and doing nothing. There was too much stress when I worked in the lab dept. People act nice to new co workers in the beginning .Then the gossip starts from the people that have been there for years. I really disliked working thier because of the people that work there in the lab.its a good hospital but thr staff needs to lear to be respectful and encouraging.

pros: I've been very lucky with my management and leadership at Trinity and continue to grow in my career here.
cons: The healthcare industry is in a real tough spot right now and things can move too slowly at Trinity sometimes, which we can't afford current state.

review_title: Great PR; not so great place to work
pros: Lots of challenging work; some really great people work there.
cons: Management is arrogant and weak at best.  Spend too much time psychoanalyzing everyone rather than analyzing what needs to be done. Passive/aggressive middle management.  There is virtually no communication from management.   This place has a long history of nepotism, luckily some of the dead wood has left.  Raises are basically non-existent for most, even if you get an excellent review.  Benefits get worse every year with increasing costs to the employee.

job_title: PCA- Nurse Extern in Grand Rapids, MI
pros:
Good team environment
Competitive work schedule- no weekends/ few holidays/ flexibility
Pay is competitive with market offerings
Extra hours usually available
$2500 tuition reimbursement
cons:
terrible benefit structure
403b plan matching works out to be approximately 2.5% 
all new grad RNs are required to enter into a residency with a financial penalty if the residency is not completed 
new grads who have completed the residency are not promoted as fast as non residency transfers from another facility

pros: Good work environment with positive future of the company.  Flexible with single parents that helps with taking care of kids
cons: Really difficult to sometimes fire people so you end up with a good deal of dead weight that really hinders the company's growth.  You have people that don't do their job but you can't get rid of them so everyone else just has to make up for their shortcomings.

review_title: Poor Management and Overbearing HR Dept
pros:
Medical benefits are pretty good compared to what's out there now.

There are some pockets of really sharp people you can work with.

You get a lot of time off compared to a lot of organizations. I believe you start with 4 weeks per calendar year and it goes up to 6 after you gain enough seniority. Sick time if you're exempt is not used out of your PTO.

Work life / Home life balance is probably the best thing going for it at this time. If you get in with a good group you can pretty much telecommute which is nice and a rare find.

Seem to actually care about their patients and populations they serve
cons:
HR dictates pretty much everything regarding performance reviews, raises, and promotions. This leaves management the ability to throw their hands up and say, "it's out of my control".

Pay is subpar, and "raises" cap out at 3.5% per year - and that is only if you are at the lower end of your pay scale and/or get exceptionally high marks on your performance review

Performance reviews are generally written by you and reviewed by your manager. Some would see this as a plus, but when it comes down to actually knowing where you stand and how you perform it's near impossible to gauge. 

Promotion plans are extremely tedious and usually span 6 months or longer. 

If you do manage to get a promotion - you get moved to the bottom of the associated pay scale. Their so-called "upside" to this is you are now eligible for higher raises at review time (you get half a percent increase more than someone at mid-point of the pay range e.g. you get 3.5% instead of 3.0%)

Expect very little opportunity for upward movement in the organization.

Pretty much no opportunity for professional training or certifications. Don't expect to grow as an employee. They won't invest in you.

Worked there for 8 1/2 years and the Organization restructured at least  half a dozen times. This could be viewed as good depending on your perspective, but it seemed as though each re-org left the organization is a worse state from my perspective.

Very beuraucratic place to work.

pros: I worked with great people. The patients were great to work with as well. It was a rewarding job, as is most in the nursing field.
cons: My supervisor was terrible. She lied to everyone and would get angry if we didn't pick up an extra shift. The pay was bad also. The company pays a lot of money for their doctors compared to other companies but can't pay their nurses or support staff as they should.

review_title: Was greate prior to merger with CHE
pros: Pay is at the higher end, ability to work from home is what keeps most people there, some really great people to work with, getting better at ensuring the technology is up to date. Prior to the merger, this was an awesome place to work, folks were on track to move up in titles and increase their skill sets.
cons: Since merger with CHE workloads are increasing, staff levels are shrinking, morale is decreasing, no opportunity for growth (especially for women, unless on the help desk side of things), and promotion plans are being ignored, delayed or cancelled. No overtime pay, on-call is required for most teams and for the mission-critical teams on-call is absolute hell. Management appears to be of the mindset to "whip the horses until they are dead, then replace with fresh ones".  Work-life balance is non-existent, expect to be called when on vacation. Expect to have your health impacted and management won't care. Lots of favoritism around training and technical conferences, only the "golden boys" get to go and no cross-training happens from the ones who do go. There's a lot of talk about "resilience" and "work-life balance", but it's all talk, no fall thru. Any physical issues caused by the workload or sleep interruptions due to on-call are written off as HR has deemed all stress as being a "mental health" issue and you'll be advised to do yoga to de-stress.

pros: Trinity is a large company, with great Mission and Core Values, there are also a lot of opportunities for people to move and advance within the organization.
cons: Because of the size and complexity of the organization, it is sometimes challenging for those who work at the corporate office to see the impact of their work at the local level, and it is equally challenging sometimes for employees at the local level to understand the work those at the corporate office are doing.

Is nothing. Management Fired me because they "heard" I was gonna quit anyways. In which I had no plans of doing.

job_title: Anam Cara in White Lake, MI
pros: great coworkers and residents, beautiful & new facility, good food, provided with all the necessary tools (gait belt, sit to stands, hoyers, etc)
cons: Management is terrible. During the interview process and orientation the Sanctuary is made out to sound amazing. Pay is decent but all the "perks" they claim to have make the job seem well worth it. They say you will receive a good amount of PTO, be able to easily transfer to any St. Joes hospital or facility, tuition reimbursement after a year(true), and have 2 anam caras and 1 nurse per "neighborhood." NOT TRUE. You can only take a day, weekend, time off by using your PTO. You can't just request a long weekend or week off months in advance as unpaid. You can only take time off if you have and use PTO. If there is one open bed in a neighborhood they call staff and tell them not to come in to save money and not have to pay employees. The DON will literally take the schedule and call anam caras off in every neighborhood on each floor if the building is not fully occupied. They will also add you to the schedule on days not on your set schedule and not ask or notify you. Then you receive an extremely rude phone call from them where they bash you and yell at you for not showing up and say they are making you work on your weekend off. The DON is also sneaky, conniving, and completely fake. She'll ask employees "what the gossip is" and if you try to do a good deed and tell her when others maybe need some help with how to do something the right way or when others are doing something that isn't right she'll call them into her office and say' "so Jane told me you were doing this or that." She schedules aides by themselves on floors that have 80% 2 person transfers, lifts, stands, etc and when the poor employees do it by themselves so the residents don't suffer she'll then threaten to revoke their license. She's also been known to threaten to revoke it if you quit, and deny transfer requests to move to one of the hospitals. It's sad that it could be a wonderful place to work if management knew how to conduct themselves, treat employees properly, and schedule the staff they DO have correctly for the sake of the residents.

review_title: Easy, but stressful job. Do a year, then start applying for something better.
job_title: IS Service Desk I in Livonia, MI
pros:
-good pay for type of work
-pto is earned every hour worked the first day you start.  It's about 12.5/hr every month, after a year about 14.5/hr every month. 
-healthcare IT exposure 
-paid holidays 
-was never messaged about going to the bathroom
-overtime, which after six months you can work from home when on OT and during bad weather, or if you have car trouble, etc.
--management does not micro manage 
-nice co-workers, including mangement
-decent benefits 
-some training. 
-management is accommodating
-most employees are full time starting, some are contingent (full time gets $19/hr, contingent starts at $20/hr).  If you do a good job, management will move you to full time (which comes with benefits/etc) in a matter of months.
cons:
-management will say advancement is encouraged, but good luck trying to move up if you don't know anyone.  I applied to a few jobs internally, and not even an email.  Just read a few of the reviews here pertaining to help desk and Trinity Health as a whole, notice a trend?
-Prepare to have new hospitals added to the help desk support list.  Meaning you will be taking more calls.  As a service desk employee, we were tasked with taking over a HUGE hospital system.  Management hired almost no additional staff, half my calls were from Columbus hospital users by the time managment fully implemented the brunt of Columbus hopstial calls being routed to our desk a few months ago.  I would not be surprised if management decided to combine Trinity Health's service desks.  The West desk is here in Livonia, while the East desk is in Newtown Square Penn.  Which means prepare for more future calls coming your way, possibly
-only 30 min for lunch, two fifteen min breaks
-sick, vacation and time off are all taken from pto earned
-an excellent employee will barley get a 4℅ raise.  If a person isn't the best expect a 2-3℅ raise, or even less
-poor communication/transparency from management at times
-very stressful due mainly to the high call volume. Forty to fifty, sometimes even sixty calls a day is the norm. 
 -holiday pay is only time and a half instead of double now
 -burnout is inevitable
 -open office environment


If you're reading this, know this is a call center job.  Despite the many cons, this job really did help me out in some ways.  It got me exposed to healthcare IT, which looks good when applying to other higher level tech jobs in the medical field.  Don't get too comfortable, that is what management wants.  Do your time, and when a year hits please start looking elsewhere, and not in help desk.  Don't get stuck in help desk, please.

Your typical faith-based organization using this as a massive loophole to make money up at the top. As a person of strong Christian faith, I hope that you stop using religion to capitalize and scrape the revenue/longevity off of this organization.

job_title: IT Administrator in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Thanks to Covid, they finally got rid of a large number of the bad employees and dead weight middle management that worked there.  Current middle management wants to be better than previous middle management.  Upper management likes to think that they care about the people below them but it is more like a political mess.  Biggest Pro is that the company is still viable during the CoronaVirus
cons:
For the longest time it was very difficult to be terminated by Trinity and at the same time, you were rewarded with promotions for long terms of service so you had a very large number of bad middle management at the company.  Guys who had been there 15+ years, that stayed there because they couldn’t get a comparable job anywhere else and were rewarded with management positions that they did not have the skills for.  They were not good employees that made even worse middle management and they were never provided with the training to treat employees with any kind of respect.  Now thanks to Covid and Trinity having to reduce a large number of unnecessary expenses, upper management was forced to review their payroll and justify what positions were necessary for the company to continue with a much lower operating budget.  In doing this, all those employees that had not been doing their job were let go.  Yes, some good people were let go too but for the most part the overall moral is good considering so much dead weight has been shed.
Advancement:  Upper management always talked about the avenues that are available for people to grow and advance at the company.  Apparently in the past, it was very easy for people without the skills to advance which may be the reason it is impossible now.  They tell you that you can advance here at Trinity so that you don’t leave to seek the advancement elsewhere.  Currently, if they decide that they are “considering” promoting you then you have to fill out a promotion plan outlining why you think you should get the promotion.  Then if your manager and about 3 others above them think that you are worthy, then you start a one year process of projects and approved work that if you successfully complete, you then have your year long plan reviewed.  IF they consider you to be worthy, you are granted the promotion.... wow.
